description:
Who’s a better scorer: Tyson Chandler or LeBron James? We'll explore how many points each player has scored...and how many they've missed!

Standards: 6.EE.2, 6.EE.6, 6.NS.5, 6.RP.1, 6.RP.2, 6.RP.3
name: Tyson v. LeBron

description:
How is health insurance like a product warranty and how is it different? In this lesson we'll use expected value to explore health insurance from a variety of perspectives.

Standards: 7.EE.3, 7.EE.4, 7.NS.3, 7.SP.5
name: Warranty for You

description:
Is it ever a good idea to buy AppleCare? We'll use percents, equations and expected value to determine whether product warranties are ever a good deal.

Standards: 6.EE.2, 6.EE.5, 6.EE.7
name: An AppleCare a Day

description:
On which day of the week were you born...and on which day will you be eligible for your senior citizen's discount? We'll use "clock arithmetic" to do some calendar math!

Standards: 6.NS.2, 6.RP.1, 6.RP.3
name: Save the Date

description:
At the end of "Les Miserables," Javert jumps from a bridge into the River Seine. We'll use quadratics to find out how high the bridge was, how fast he was going and whether he may have survived!

Standards: F.BF.1, F.BF.2, F.IF.3, F.IF.6
name: Le Pont de Javert

description:
Over the course of your lifetime, how much time will you spend tying your shoes? Sleeping? Swallowing food? We’ll explore how little moments add up to a lifetime, and how we spend our time.

Standards: 6.RP.1, 6.RP.2, 7.RP.1, 7.RP.2
name: Time of Our Lives

description:
How long would it take to burn off a Big Mac Extra Value Meal, and what would happen if instead of listing calories, restaurants had to specify nutritional information in terms of exercise?

Standards: 6.NS.3, 6.RP.2, 6.RP.3
name: New-tritional Info

description:
Hybrid cars promise better fuel economy than their all-gas alternatives. When is it a good idea to buy a hybrid...and when it is not?

Standards: 6.RP.2, 7.G.1, 7.RP.3
name: Civic Hybrid

description:
Led Zeppelin sings:  There’s a lady who’s sure all that glitters is gold, and she’s buying the stairway to heaven.  But how long will it take her to climb it?

Standards: 5.MD.1, 6.RP.1, 6.RP.2, 6.RP.3, 7.EE.3
name: Stairway to Heaven

description:
Imagine a country with an average income of $50,000.  That sounds like a lot, but is it?  In this lesson we’ll use the income distributions of various hypothetical countries to explore the difference between “average” and “typical.”

Standards: 6.SP.2, 6.SP.3, 6.SP.4, 6.SP.5
name: Wealth of Nations

description:
Virginia has the vainest drivers in the country. In this lesson we’ll explore the mathematics behind vanity plates. How many possible messages are there, and what would yours say?

Standards: 7.SP.8
name: VA-NITY PL88

description:
Theo & Rudy share a wireless plan. We'll use proportions to estimate how many minutes, texts & data they'll use in a month, and discuss how they should split the bill.

Standards: 6.RP.2, 6.RP.3, 7.RP.1, 7.RP.2, 7.RP.3
name: Family Plan

description:
When you watch TV, why doesn’t the picture always fit the screen, and what’s the math behind those black bars? We'll use aspect ratios and use proportions to find out.

Standards: 6.RP.1, 6.RP.3, 7.G.1, 7.RP.2, 7.RP.3
name: Letterboxing

description:
When you buy concert tickets, what percent of the total price goes towards fees? From service fees to delivery fees, we’ll explore how much we're really paying for a ticket.

Standards: 6.RP.3, 7.RP.3
name: Face Value

description:
When you go trick-or-treating on Halloween, how much enjoyment do you get from each additional piece of candy? We'll explore marginal vs. total enjoyment, and learn a little calculus along the way!

Standards: 8.EE.1, 8.F.1, 8.F.2, 8.F.5, F.IF.4, F.IF.6
name: Sweet Tooth

description:
Can a ratio help us live happier lives? We'll explore the jen ratio and learn how to balance positive & negative influences.

Standards: 6.RP.1, 6.RP.2
name: Jen Playlist

description:
Scientists estimate that on Halloween 2011 the global population reached 7 billion. In this lesson we’ll explore the exponential growth of the world's population.

Standards: F.BF.1, F.BF.2, F.BF.5, F.LE.5
name: 7 Billion

description:
What does “10” mean?  Is it necessarily the same thing as “ten?”  In this lesson we’ll learn how to count using different bases, and will travel to other planets to learn how aliens count.

Standards: 5.NBT.1
name: Ace of Base

description:
How fast is the world spinning in miles per hour?  In this lesson we’ll use unit rates to determine the speed at which the Earth rotates around the Equator, Tropic of Cancer and the Arctic Circle.

Standards: 6.RP.2, 6.RP.3
name: As the World Turns

description:
On Sept. 15, 2010, YouTube user Ryan S. shaved his head, then took picture of himself every day for a year. We’ll use linear equations to explore how hair grows over time.

Standards: 8.EE.5, 8.EE.6, 8.EE.7, 8.EE.8, 8.F.3, 8.F.4, 8.F.5
name: Locks of Love

description:
The Domino’s website allows you to build your own pizzas, but doesn’t specify how much they cost.  We’ll use linear equations to find the base price (y-intercept) and cost per additional topping (slope) to figure out how much Domino’s is really charging for pizza.

Standards: 8.EE.5, 8.EE.6, 8.EE.7, 8.EE.8, 8.F.3, 8.F.4, 8.F.5
name: Domino Effect

description:
Papa John’s pizzas come in four sizes: S, M, L & XL.  But which is the best deal?  We’ll calculate the area of each circle and the cost per square inch to find out.

Standards: 7.G.4, 7.NS.3, 7.RP.1, 7.RP.2, 7.RP.3
name: Pizza Pi

description:
China’s Xie Quiping holds the Guinness World Record for the longest hair. In this lesson we’ll use rates, ratios & proportions to explore find out how fast hair and nails grow. Think you can beat the world record?

Standards: 6.RP.2, 6.RP.3, 7.RP.1, 7.RP.2, 7.RP.3
name: Beauty Shop of Horrors

description:
Olympic sprinter Usain Bolt is crazy fast. He's also crazy tall. Does his height give him an unfair advantage? We’ll see what would happen if athletes ran distances proportional to their heights. Would Bolt still have won the gold?


Standards: 7.RP.1, 7.RP.2, 7.RP.3
name: On Your Mark

description:
Want to laugh out loud and teach math at the same time? We’ll use ratios & proportions to explore photographic trickery: using forced perspective to change the scale to make people appear very small, or very, very big.

Standards: 7.G.1, 7.RP.2
name: Giants Are Coming!

description:
According to researchers in Australia, every hour that you watch television reduces your lifespan by 22 minutes. We’ll use tables, graphs & equations to explore how our habits today affects how much time we have left tomorrow.

Standards: 8.EE.5, 8.EE.7, 8.F.1, 8.F.3, 8.F.4, 8.F.5
name: 22 Minutes

description:
If two players shoot a different number of foul shots, how do you decide who did better?  In this lesson we’ll use fractions, percents and graphs to determine who’s the better shooter: Mr. White or Mr. Black

Standards: 6.RP.1, 6.RP.2, 6.RP.3
name: From the Line

description:
Does listening to music affect your heart rate? If so, could a fast enough song cause you to have a heart attack?

Standards: 8.EE.6, 8.EE.7, 8.F.3, 8.F.4, 8.SP.1, 8.SP.2, 8.SP.3
name: Can Music Kill You?

description:
How are the stars arranged on the American flag?  We'll use factors to explore the math of this star spangled banner, from past to present...to future.

Standards: 4.OA.4
name: Star Spangled Banner

description:
We’ll learn how to use the order of operations, discuss common errors, solve puzzles and find out why PEMDAS is a bad word.  We’ll end by taking the Immunity Challenge from the CBS show Survivor.

Standards: 6.EE.3, 7.NS.1, 7.NS.3
name: PEMDASurvivor

description:
We’ll use the order of operations to learn about body mass index. We'll discuss different ways of writing the formula, determine the weight status of famous celebrities and find out how the height and weight affect the BMI.

Standards: 6.EE.2, 6.EE.5, 6.EE.6, 6.EE.8, 6.EE.9
name: Hi, BMI

description:
We'll construct a scale model of the White House to explore suface area and volume. How much does it cost to paint and heat America's most famous home?

Standards: 7.G.1, 7.G.6
name: 1600 Pennsylvania

description:
We’ll learn how to use mental math to estimate tips in a restaurant. We'll also discuss restaurant etiquette. When is it okay to leave less than 15%, and what's the fairest way to split the bill?

Standards: 7.EE.3, 7.RP.3
name: Tip Jar

description:
We'll travel back in time to build squares with Pythagoras & Co. We'll learn how to square numbers, find square roots and explore what it means for numbers to be irrational. (Warning: this lesson may fry your students' brains!)

Standards: 8.EE.2, 8.NS.1, 8.NS.2
name: Roots of Squares

description:
We'll play Pythagoras’ favorite game: the Square Root Game. The goal is to win as many gold coins as possible by correctly identifying perfect squares and calculating their square roots.

Standards: 8.EE.2
name: Square Root Game

description:
According to scientists, the more you remember something, the less accurate the memory becomes. We'll use linear vs. exponential models to explore how memory works. Think you can trust your memory? Think again!

Standards: F.BF.2, F.IF.1, F.IF.2, F.IF.8, F.LE.1, F.LE.2, F.LE.5
name: I Remember

description:
In the game show The Biggest Loser, the winner is the contestant who loses the most weight. But how should they calculate this: in pounds or as a percent?

Standards: 6.RP.3, 7.RP.3
name: Biggest Loser

description:
The British website RED5.co.uk allows customers to customize its Vibe watch. In this lesson we’ll use permutations to explore how many colour combinations are possible.

Standards: 7.SP.8
name: Watch This

description:
Are traditional grading scales fair?  We’ll see how Bart, Martin & Milhouse did on their two math tests and what they should get on their report cards.

Standards: 6.RP.3, 6.SP.4, 6.SP.5
name: Grading Scales of Justice

description:
There’s a little donut stand in Charlottesville, Virginia that sells wonderful fresh donuts: one for $2, two for $3, three for $4, etc.  In this lesson we’ll explore what happens to the total cost, average cost and marginal cost as we buy more and more of them.  

Standards: 8.EE.5, 8.EE.7, 8.EE.8, 8.F.1, 8.F.2, 8.F.3, 8.F.4, 8.F.5, F.IF.1, F.IF.2, F.IF.4, F.IF.5, F.LE.1
name: Donut Stand

description:
How big is Switzerland's Gotthard Tunnel, and how many jars of peanut butter could you fill with all the dirt? We'll calculate the volume of cylinders to find out.

Standards: 5.MD.1, 5.MD.2, 5.MD.3, 5.MD.4, 8.EE.3, 8.G.9
name: Inside Scoop

description:
What are the odds of finding life on other planets?  What are the odds of finding a boy- or girlfriend on this one? We'll multiply fractions to find out!

Standards: 5.NF.4, 5.NF.6
name: Are We Alone?

description:
How big is a 42-inch TV, really? We'll learn how to use the aspect ratio & diagonal length to calculate the area of a TV screen.

Standards: 8.G.7, G.SRT.8
name: Pythagorean TV

description:
How long would it take a teacher to earn what LeBron James does in a year? We'll explore how much people earn, from Snooki to the president.

Standards: 4.MD.1, 4.MD.2, 5.MD.1
name: Payday

description:
How has the iPod depreciated over time? We'll use eBay & exponential decay to find out.

Standards: F.BF.2, F.BF.5, F.IF.8, F.LE.1, F.LE.2, F.LE.3, F.LE.4
name: iPod dPreciation

description:
What's the best way to burn fat when you exercise? We'll use PEMDAS to find out how different heart rate zones keep us healthy & fit.

Standards: 6.EE.2, 6.EE.6, 6.EE.9
name: Fat Burner

description:
If you could travel back in time, how many people would you be related to? We'll use exponential growth to find out.

Standards: 6.EE.1, 6.EE.2, 6.EE.6, 6.EE.9, F.BF.2, F.BF.5, F.LE.2, F.LE.4
name: Family Tree

description:
How are the Fibonacci Numbers & Golden Ratio related, and what do they tell us about nature...and ourselves?

Standards: 4.OA.5, 6.RP.1
name: Leonardo Numbers

description:
How have video game consoles changed over time?  We'll use exponential growth to explore whether they've followed Moore's Law.

Standards: F.IF.7, F.IF.8, F.LE.1, F.LE.2
name: XBOX Xponential

description:
Is Wheel of Fortune rigged?  We'll analyze the wheel to predict how often each amount should come up, and then watch an episode to see how often it really does.

Standards: 6.RP.3, 6.SP.4, 6.SP.5, 7.SP.5, 7.SP.6, 7.SP.7
name: Wheel of Fortune?

description:
What’s the math behind losing weight?  We'll use the order of operations (PEMDAS) to explore how eating and exercise affect body weight.

Standards: 6.EE.2, 6.EE.6
name: Calories In, Calories Out

description:
Do people with small feet pay more for shoes?  We'll find out how much different sized shoes cost per ounce and explore what would happen if Nike charged by weight.

Standards: 6.RP.1, 6.RP.2, 6.RP.3
name: Big Foot Conspiracy

description:
The iPhone is 2.3 inches wide x 4.5 inches tall. We'll use this to explore ratios and proportions, from designing billboards to a new iPhone Nano.

Standards: 7.G.1, 7.RP.2
name: iPhone dMensions

description:
Is buying a specialty pizza from Papa John's a good deal? In this lesson, we'll use percents to find out how much we're actually saving, and how to buy the right pizza.

Standards: 7.EE.4, 7.G.4, 7.RP.3, 8.EE.8, 8.F.1, 8.F.2, 8.F.3
name: Go Big, Papa?

description:
Nike iD allows you to customize a pair of shoes. How many color combinations are possible?  Is this a good idea, or can it lead to "paralysis by analysis?"

Standards: 7.SP.8, 8.EE.3
name: Pimp My Feet

description:
In most places, fines for speeding are based on how fast you’re driving over the speed limit. We’ll write and solve equations to find out if speeding tickets are calculated fairly.

Standards: 8.EE.5, 8.EE.7, 8.EE.8, 8.F.1, 8.F.2, 8.F.3, 8.F.4
name: Not So Fast

description:
How much does the iPad cost, and is the pricing linear? In this lesson, we'll use linear functions to explore how much Apple charges for its products.

Standards: 8.EE.6, 8.EE.7, 8.F.1, 8.F.3, 8.F.4
name: iCost

description:
Would a 51 foot ladder be long enough to climb a 50 foot wall?  In this lesson, we'll use the Pythagorean Theorem to explore everything from ladders to fire trucks to a stairway to heaven.

Standards: 8.G.7, G.SRT.8
name: 51-Foot Ladder
